title: Dislocated Shoulder
summary: First aid for shoulder dislocation focusing on immobilization and pain relief. Do not attempt to relocate the shoulder.

steps.title: Recognize Dislocation
steps.description: Look for shoulder appearing out of place, severe pain, inability to move arm, visible bump or depression. Person often holds arm slightly away from body. Do NOT attempt to pop shoulder back in place.

steps.title: Support the Arm
steps.description: Help person support injured arm in most comfortable position. Usually this is with elbow bent and arm across chest. Use pillows or folded blankets to maintain this position.

steps.title: Immobilize with Sling
steps.description: Apply sling to support arm weight. Use triangular bandage or improvise with shirt or jacket. Tie sling around neck. Add swathe (band around chest and arm) to prevent movement.

steps.title: Apply Ice for Pain
steps.description: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to shoulder area. Ice for 15-20 minutes to reduce pain and swelling. Do not apply ice directly to skin. Reapply every hour if needed.

steps.title: Seek Medical Care
steps.description: Transport to emergency room immediately. Shoulder must be relocated by medical professional. Check fingers for circulation (color, warmth, ability to move). Remove rings before swelling increases.

warnings: Never attempt to relocate a dislocated shoulder - this can cause nerve and blood vessel damage
Repeated dislocations can occur more easily
May have associated fractures that aren't visible
whenToSeekHelp: Always seek immediate medical care for dislocated shoulder
Call 911 if person shows signs of shock
Seek urgent care if fingers are numb or blue
preventionTips: Strengthen shoulder muscles with regular exercise
Avoid arm positions that previously caused dislocation
Use proper technique in sports and lifting
